text: In the first year of King Cyrus of Persia, in fulfillment of the Lord’s message spoken through Jeremiah, the Lord motivated King Cyrus of Persia to issue a proclamation throughout his kingdom and also to put it in writing. It read:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“This is what King Cyrus of Persia says:
“‘The Lord God of heaven has given me all the kingdoms of the earth. He has appointed me to build a temple for him in Jerusalem, which is in Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone of his people among you (may his God be with him!) may go up to Jerusalem, which is in Judah, and may build the temple of the Lord God of Israel—he is the God who is in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone who survives in any of those places where he is a resident foreigner must be helped by his neighbors with silver, gold, equipment, and animals, along with voluntary offerings for the temple of God which is in Jerusalem.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the leaders of Judah and Benjamin, along with the priests and the Levites—all those whose mind God had stirred—got ready to go up in order to build the temple of the Lord in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: All their neighbors assisted them with silver utensils, gold, equipment, animals, and expensive gifts, not to mention all the voluntary offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then King Cyrus brought out the vessels of the Lord’s temple which Nebuchadnezzar had brought from Jerusalem and had displayed in the temple of his gods.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Cyrus of Persia entrusted them to Mithredath the treasurer, who counted them out to Sheshbazzar the leader of the Judahite exiles.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The inventory of these items was as follows:
30 gold basins,
1,000 silver basins,
29 silver utensils,
speaker: Narrator

text:
30 gold bowls,
410 other silver bowls,
and 1,000 other vessels.
speaker: Narrator

text: All these gold and silver vessels totaled 5,400. Sheshbazzar brought them all along when the captives were brought up from Babylon to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the people of the province who were going up, from the captives of the exile whom King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon had forced into exile in Babylon. They returned to Jerusalem and Judah, each to his own city.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They came with Zerubbabel, Jeshua, Nehemiah, Seraiah, Reelaiah, Mordecai, Bilshan, Mispar, Bigvai, Rehum, and Baanah.
The number of Israelites was as follows:
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Parosh: 2,172;
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Shephatiah: 372;
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Arah: 775;
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Pahath Moab (from the line of Jeshua and Joab): 2,812;
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Elam: 1,254;
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Zattu: 945;
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Zaccai: 760;
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Bani: 642;
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Bebai: 623;
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Azgad: 1,222;
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Adonikam: 666;
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Bigvai: 2,056;
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Adin: 454;
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Ater (through Hezekiah): 98;
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Bezai: 323;
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Jorah: 112;
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Hashum: 223;
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Gibbar: 95.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of Bethlehem: 123;
speaker: Narrator

text: the men of Netophah: 56;
speaker: Narrator

text: the men of Anathoth: 128;
speaker: Narrator

text: the men of the family of Azmaveth: 42;
speaker: Narrator

text: the men of Kiriath Jearim, Kephirah and Beeroth: 743;
speaker: Narrator

text: the men of Ramah and Geba: 621;
speaker: Narrator

text: the men of Micmash: 122;
speaker: Narrator

text: the men of Bethel and Ai: 223;
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Nebo: 52;
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Magbish: 156;
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of the other Elam: 1,254;
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Harim: 320;
speaker: Narrator

text: the men of Lod, Hadid, and Ono: 725;
speaker: Narrator

text: the men of Jericho: 345;
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Senaah: 3,630.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priests: the descendants of Jedaiah (through the family of Jeshua): 973;
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Immer: 1,052;
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Pashhur: 1,247;
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Harim: 1,017.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Levites: the descendants of Jeshua and Kadmiel (through the line of Hodaviah): 74.
speaker: Narrator

text: The singers: the descendants of Asaph: 128.
speaker: Narrator

text: The gatekeepers: the descendants of Shallum, the descendants of Ater, the descendants of Talmon, the descendants of Akkub, the descendants of Hatita, and the descendants of Shobai: 139.
speaker: Narrator

text: The temple servants: the descendants of Ziha, the descendants of Hasupha, the descendants of Tabbaoth,
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Keros, the descendants of Siaha, the descendants of Padon,
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Lebanah, the descendants of Hagabah, the descendants of Akkub,
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Hagab, the descendants of Shalmai, the descendants of Hanan,
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Giddel, the descendants of Gahar, the descendants of Reaiah,
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Rezin, the descendants of Nekoda, the descendants of Gazzam,
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Uzzah, the descendants of Paseah, the descendants of Besai,
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Asnah, the descendants of Meunim, the descendants of Nephussim,
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Bakbuk, the descendants of Hakupha, the descendants of Harhur,
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Bazluth, the descendants of Mehida, the descendants of Harsha,
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Barkos, the descendants of Sisera, the descendants of Temah,
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Neziah, and the descendants of Hatipha.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of the servants of Solomon: the descendants of Sotai, the descendants of Hassophereth, the descendants of Peruda,
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Jaala, the descendants of Darkon, the descendants of Giddel,
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Shephatiah, the descendants of Hattil, the descendants of Pokereth Hazzebaim, and the descendants of Ami.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the temple servants and the descendants of the servants of Solomon: 392.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the ones that came up from Tel Melah, Tel Harsha, Kerub, Addon, and Immer (although they were unable to certify their family connection or their ancestry, as to whether they really were from Israel):
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Delaiah, the descendants of Tobiah, and the descendants of Nekoda: 652.
speaker: Narrator

text: And from among the priests: the descendants of Hobaiah, the descendants of Hakkoz, and the descendants of Barzillai (who had taken a wife from the daughters of Barzillai the Gileadite and was called by that name).
speaker: Narrator

text: They searched for their records in the genealogical materials, but did not find them. They were therefore excluded from the priesthood.
speaker: Narrator

text: The governor instructed them not to eat any of the sacred food until there was a priest who could consult the Urim and Thummim.
speaker: Narrator

text: The entire group numbered 42,360,
speaker: Narrator

text: not counting their male and female servants, who numbered 7,337. They also had 200 male and female singers
speaker: Narrator

text: and 736 horses, 245 mules,
speaker: Narrator

text: 435 camels, and 6,720 donkeys.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they came to the Lord’s temple in Jerusalem, some of the family leaders offered voluntary offerings for the temple of God in order to rebuild it on its site.
speaker: Narrator

text: As they were able, they gave to the treasury for this work 61,000 drachmas of gold, 5,000 minas of silver, and 100 priestly robes.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priests, the Levites, some of the people, the singers, the gatekeepers, and the temple servants lived in their towns, and all the rest of Israel lived in their towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the seventh month arrived and the Israelites were living in their towns, the people assembled in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jeshua the son of Jozadak and his priestly colleagues and Zerubbabel son of Shealtiel and his colleagues started to build the altar of the God of Israel so they could offer burnt offerings on it as required by the law of Moses the man of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: They established the altar on its foundations, even though they were in terror of the local peoples, and they offered burnt offerings on it to the Lord, both the morning and the evening offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: They observed the Feast of Shelters as required and offered the proper number of daily burnt offerings according to the requirement for each day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Afterward they offered the continual burnt offerings and those for the new moons and those for all the holy assemblies of the Lord and all those that were being voluntarily offered to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the first day of the seventh month they began to offer burnt offerings to the Lord. However, the Lord’s temple was not at that time established.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they provided money for the masons and carpenters, and food, beverages, and olive oil for the people of Sidon and Tyre, so that they would bring cedar timber from Lebanon to the seaport at Joppa, in accord with the edict of King Cyrus of Persia.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the second year after they had come to the temple of God in Jerusalem, in the second month, Zerubbabel the son of Shealtiel and Jeshua the son of Jozadak initiated the work, along with the rest of their associates, the priests and the Levites, and all those who were coming to Jerusalem from the exile. They appointed the Levites who were at least twenty years old to take charge of the work on the Lord’s temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Jeshua appointed both his sons and his relatives, Kadmiel and his sons (the sons of Yehudah), to take charge of the workers in the temple of God, along with the sons of Henadad, their sons, and their relatives the Levites.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the builders established the Lord’s temple, the priests, ceremonially attired and with their clarions, and the Levites (the sons of Asaph) with their cymbals, stood to praise the Lord according to the instructions left by King David of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
With antiphonal response they sang, praising and glorifying the Lord:
“For he is good;
his loyal love toward Israel is forever.” 
All the people gave a loud shout as they praised the Lord when the temple of the Lord was established.
speaker: Narrator

text: Many of the priests, the Levites, and the leaders—older people who had seen with their own eyes the former temple while it was still established—were weeping loudly, and many others raised their voice in a joyous shout.
speaker: Narrator

text: People were unable to tell the difference between the sound of joyous shouting and the sound of the people’s weeping, for the people were shouting so loudly that the sound was heard a long way off.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the enemies of Judah and Benjamin learned that the former exiles were building a temple for the Lord God of Israel,
speaker: Narrator

text: they came to Zerubbabel and the leaders and said to them, “Let us help you build, for like you we seek your God and we have been sacrificing to him from the time of King Esarhaddon of Assyria, who brought us here.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Zerubbabel, Jeshua, and the rest of the leaders of Israel said to them, “You have no right to help us build the temple of our God. We will build it by ourselves for the Lord God of Israel, just as King Cyrus, the king of Persia, has commanded us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the local people began to discourage the people of Judah and to dishearten them from building.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were hiring advisers to oppose them, so as to frustrate their plans, throughout the time of King Cyrus of Persia until the reign of King Darius of Persia.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the beginning of the reign of Ahasuerus they filed an accusation against the inhabitants of Judah and Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And during the reign of Artaxerxes, Bishlam, Mithredath, Tabeel, and the rest of their colleagues wrote to King Artaxerxes of Persia. This letter was first written in Aramaic but then translated.
[What follows is in Aramaic]
speaker: Narrator

text: Rehum the commander and Shimshai the scribe wrote a letter concerning Jerusalem to King Artaxerxes as follows:
speaker: Narrator

text: From Rehum the commander, Shimshai the scribe, and the rest of their colleagues—the judges, the rulers, the officials, the secretaries, the Erechites, the Babylonians, the people of Susa (that is, the Elamites),
speaker: Narrator

text: and the rest of the nations whom the great and noble Ashurbanipal deported and settled in the cities of Samaria and other places in Trans-Euphrates.
speaker: Narrator

text:
(This is a copy of the letter they sent to him.)
“To King Artaxerxes, from your servants in Trans-Euphrates:
speaker: Narrator

text: Now let the king be aware that the Jews who came up to us from you have gone to Jerusalem. They are rebuilding that rebellious and odious city. They are completing its walls and repairing its foundations.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let the king also be aware that if this city is built and its walls are completed, no more tax, custom, or toll will be paid, and the royal treasury will suffer loss.
speaker: Narrator

text: In light of the fact that we are loyal to the king, and since it does not seem appropriate to us that the king should sustain damage, we are sending the king this information
speaker: Narrator

text: so that he may initiate a search of the records of his predecessors and discover in those records that this city is rebellious and injurious to both kings and provinces, producing internal revolts from long ago. It is for this very reason that this city was destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text: We therefore are informing the king that if this city is rebuilt and its walls are completed, you will not retain control of this portion of Trans-Euphrates.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The king sent the following response:
“To Rehum the commander, Shimshai the scribe, and the rest of their colleagues who live in Samaria and other parts of Trans-Euphrates: Greetings!
speaker: Narrator

text: The letter you sent to us has been translated and read in my presence.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I gave orders, and it was determined that this city from long ago has been engaging in insurrection against kings. It has continually engaged in rebellion and revolt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Powerful kings have been over Jerusalem who ruled throughout the entire Trans-Euphrates and who were the beneficiaries of tribute, custom, and toll.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now give orders that these men cease their work and that this city not be rebuilt until such time as I so instruct.
speaker: Narrator

text: Exercise appropriate caution so that there is no negligence in this matter. Why should danger increase to the point that the king sustains damage?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then, as soon as the copy of the letter from King Artaxerxes was read in the presence of Rehum, Shimshai the scribe, and their colleagues, they proceeded promptly to the Jews in Jerusalem and stopped them with threat of armed force.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the work on the temple of God in Jerusalem came to a halt. It remained halted until the second year of the reign of King Darius of Persia.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the prophets Haggai and Zechariah son of Iddo prophesied concerning the Jews who were in Judah and Jerusalem in the name of the God of Israel who was over them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Zerubbabel the son of Shealtiel and Jeshua the son of Jozadak began to rebuild the temple of God in Jerusalem. The prophets of God were with them, supporting them.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time Tattenai governor of Trans-Euphrates, Shethar-Bozenai, and their colleagues came to them and asked, “Who gave you authority to rebuild this temple and to complete this structure?”
speaker: Narrator

text: They also asked them, “What are the names of the men who are building this edifice?”
speaker: Narrator

text: But God was watching over the elders of Judah, and they were not stopped until a report could be dispatched to Darius and a letter could be sent back concerning this.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is a copy of the letter that Tattenai governor of Trans-Euphrates, Shethar-Bozenai, and his colleagues (who were the officials of Trans-Euphrates) sent to King Darius.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The report they sent to him was written as follows:
“To King Darius: All greetings!
speaker: Narrator

text: Let it be known to the king that we have gone to the province of Judah, to the temple of the great God. It is being built with large stones, and timbers are being placed in the walls. This work is being done with all diligence and is prospering in their hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: We inquired of those elders, asking them, ‘Who gave you the authority to rebuild this temple and to complete this structure?’
speaker: Narrator

text: We also inquired of their names in order to inform you, so that we might write the names of the men who were their leaders.
speaker: Narrator

text: They responded to us in the following way: ‘We are servants of the God of heaven and earth. We are rebuilding the temple which was previously built many years ago. A great king of Israel built it and completed it.
speaker: Narrator

text: But after our ancestors angered the God of heaven, he delivered them into the hands of King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon, the Chaldean, who destroyed this temple and exiled the people to Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text: But in the first year of King Cyrus of Babylon, King Cyrus enacted a decree to rebuild this temple of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even the gold and silver vessels of the temple of God that Nebuchadnezzar had taken from the temple in Jerusalem and had brought to the palace of Babylon—even those things King Cyrus brought from the palace of Babylon and presented to a man by the name of Sheshbazzar whom he had appointed as governor.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to him, “Take these vessels and go deposit them in the temple in Jerusalem, and let the house of God be rebuilt in its proper location.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then this Sheshbazzar went and laid the foundations of the temple of God in Jerusalem. From that time to the present moment it has been in the process of being rebuilt, although it is not yet finished.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now if the king is so inclined, let a search be conducted in the royal archives there in Babylon in order to determine whether King Cyrus did in fact issue orders for this temple of God to be rebuilt in Jerusalem. Then let the king send us a decision concerning this matter.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Darius the king issued orders, and they searched in the archives of the treasury which were deposited there in Babylon.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A scroll was found in the citadel of Ecbatana which is in the province of Media, and it was inscribed as follows:
“Memorandum:
speaker: Narrator

text: In the first year of his reign, King Cyrus gave orders concerning the temple of God in Jerusalem: ‘Let the temple be rebuilt as a place where sacrifices are offered. Let its foundations be set in place. Its height is to be 90 feet and its width 90 feet,
speaker: Narrator

text: with three layers of large stones and one layer of timber. The expense is to be subsidized by the royal treasury.
speaker: Narrator

text: Furthermore, let the gold and silver vessels of the temple of God, which Nebuchadnezzar brought from the temple in Jerusalem and carried to Babylon, be returned and brought to their proper place in the temple in Jerusalem. Let them be deposited in the temple of God.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now Tattenai governor of Trans-Euphrates, Shethar-Bozenai, and their colleagues, the officials of Trans-Euphrates—all of you stay far away from there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Leave the work on this temple of God alone. Let the governor of the Jews and the elders of the Jews rebuild this temple of God in its proper place.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I also hereby issue orders as to what you are to do with those elders of the Jews in order to rebuild this temple of God. From the royal treasury, from the taxes of Trans-Euphrates, the complete costs are to be given to these men so that there may be no interruption of the work.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whatever is needed—whether oxen or rams or lambs for burnt offerings for the God of heaven or wheat or salt or wine or oil, as required by the priests who are in Jerusalem—must be given to them daily without any neglect,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that they may be offering incense to the God of heaven and may be praying for the good fortune of the king and his family.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I hereby give orders that if anyone changes this directive a beam is to be pulled out from his house and he is to be raised up and impaled on it, and his house is to be reduced to a rubbish heap for this indiscretion.
speaker: Narrator

text: May God who makes his name to reside there overthrow any king or nation who reaches out to cause such change so as to destroy this temple of God in Jerusalem. I, Darius, have given orders. Let them be carried out with precision!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Tattenai governor of Trans-Euphrates, Shethar-Bozenai, and their colleagues acted accordingly—with precision, just as Darius the king had given instructions.
speaker: Narrator

text: The elders of the Jews continued building and prospering, while at the same time Haggai the prophet and Zechariah the son of Iddo continued prophesying. They built and brought it to completion by the command of the God of Israel and by the command of Cyrus and Darius and Artaxerxes king of Persia.
speaker: Narrator

text: They finished this temple on the third day of the month Adar, which is the sixth year of the reign of King Darius.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people of Israel—the priests, the Levites, and the rest of the exiles—observed the dedication of this temple of God with joy.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the dedication of this temple of God they offered 100 bulls, 200 rams, 400 lambs, and 12 male goats for the sin of all Israel, according to the number of the tribes of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: They appointed the priests by their divisions and the Levites by their divisions over the worship of God at Jerusalem, in accord with the book of Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: The exiles observed the Passover on the fourteenth day of the first month.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priests and the Levites had purified themselves, every last one, and they all were ceremonially pure. They sacrificed the Passover lamb for all the exiles, for their colleagues the priests, and for themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites who were returning from the exile ate it, along with all those who had joined them in separating themselves from the uncleanness of the nations of the land to seek the Lord God of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: They observed the Feast of Unleavened Bread for seven days with joy, for the Lord had given them joy and had changed the opinion of the king of Assyria toward them so that he assisted them in the work on the temple of God, the God of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now after these things had happened, during the reign of King Artaxerxes of Persia, Ezra came up from Babylon. Ezra was the son of Seraiah, who was the son of Azariah, who was the son of Hilkiah,
speaker: Narrator

text: who was the son of Shallum, who was the son of Zadok, who was the son of Ahitub,
speaker: Narrator

text: who was the son of Amariah, who was the son of Azariah, who was the son of Meraioth,
speaker: Narrator

text: who was the son of Zerahiah, who was the son of Uzzi, who was the son of Bukki,
speaker: Narrator

text: who was the son of Abishua, who was the son of Phinehas, who was the son of Eleazar, who was the son of Aaron the chief priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: This Ezra is the one who came up from Babylon. He was a scribe who was skilled in the law of Moses which the Lord God of Israel had given. The king supplied him with everything he requested, for the hand of the Lord his God was on him.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the seventh year of King Artaxerxes, Ezra brought up to Jerusalem some of the Israelites and some of the priests, the Levites, the attendants, the gatekeepers, and the temple servants.
speaker: Narrator

text: He entered Jerusalem in the fifth month of the seventh year of the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the first day of the first month he had determined to make the ascent from Babylon, and on the first day of the fifth month he arrived at Jerusalem, for the good hand of his God was on him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Ezra had dedicated himself to the study of the law of the Lord, to its observance, and to teaching its statutes and judgments in Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: What follows is a copy of the letter that King Artaxerxes gave to Ezra the priestly scribe. Ezra was a scribe in matters pertaining to the commandments of the Lord and his statutes over Israel:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Artaxerxes, king of kings, to Ezra the priest, a scribe of the law of the God of heaven:
speaker: Narrator

text: I have now issued a decree that anyone in my kingdom from the people of Israel—even the priests and Levites—who wishes to do so may go up with you to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are authorized by the king and his seven advisers to inquire concerning Judah and Jerusalem, according to the law of your God which is in your possession,
speaker: Narrator

text: and to bring silver and gold which the king and his advisers have freely contributed to the God of Israel, who resides in Jerusalem,
speaker: Narrator

text: along with all the silver and gold that you may collect throughout all the province of Babylon and the contributions of the people and the priests for the temple of their God which is in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: With this money you should be sure to purchase bulls, rams, and lambs, along with the appropriate meal offerings and libations. You should bring them to the altar of the temple of your God which is in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: You may do whatever seems appropriate to you and your colleagues with the rest of the silver and the gold, in keeping with the will of your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Deliver to the God of Jerusalem the vessels that are given to you for the service of the temple of your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the needs for the temple of your God that you may have to supply, you may do so from the royal treasury.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I, King Artaxerxes, hereby issue orders to all the treasurers of Trans-Euphrates, that you precisely execute all that Ezra the priestly scribe of the law of the God of heaven may request of you—
speaker: Narrator

text: up to 100 talents of silver, 100 cors of wheat, 100 baths of wine, 100 baths of olive oil, and unlimited salt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Everything that the God of heaven has required should be precisely done for the temple of the God of heaven. Why should there be wrath against the empire of the king and his sons?
speaker: Narrator

text: Furthermore, be aware of the fact that you have no authority to impose tax, tribute, or toll on any of the priests, the Levites, the musicians, the doorkeepers, the temple servants, or the attendants at the temple of this God.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now you, Ezra, in keeping with the wisdom of your God which you possess, appoint judges and court officials who can arbitrate cases on behalf of all the people who are in Trans-Euphrates who know the laws of your God. Those who do not know this law should be taught.
speaker: Narrator

text: Everyone who does not observe both the law of your God and the law of the king will be completely liable to the appropriate penalty, whether it is death or banishment or confiscation of property or detainment in prison.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Blessed be the Lord God of our fathers, who so moved in the heart of the king to so honor the temple of the Lord which is in Jerusalem!
speaker: Narrator

text: He has also conferred his favor on me before the king, his advisers, and all the influential leaders of the king. I gained strength as the hand of the Lord my God was on me, and I gathered leaders from Israel to go up with me.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the leaders and those enrolled with them by genealogy who were coming up with me from Babylon during the reign of King Artaxerxes:
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
the son of Shecaniah;
from the descendants of Parosh, Zechariah, and with him were enrolled by genealogy 150 men;
speaker: Narrator

text: from the descendants of Pahath Moab, Eliehoenai son of Zerahiah, and with him 200 men;
speaker: Narrator

text: from the descendants of Zattu, Shecaniah son of Jahaziel, and with him 300 men;
speaker: Narrator

text: from the descendants of Adin, Ebed son of Jonathan, and with him 50 men;
speaker: Narrator

text: from the descendants of Elam, Jeshaiah son of Athaliah, and with him 70 men;
speaker: Narrator

text: from the descendants of Shephatiah, Zebadiah son of Michael, and with him 80 men;
speaker: Narrator

text: from the descendants of Joab, Obadiah son of Jehiel, and with him 218 men;
speaker: Narrator

text: from the descendants of Bani, Shelomith son of Josiphiah, and with him 160 men;
speaker: Narrator

text: from the descendants of Bebai, Zechariah son of Bebai, and with him 28 men;
speaker: Narrator

text: from the descendants of Azgad, Johanan son of Hakkatan, and with him 110 men;
speaker: Narrator

text: from the descendants of Adonikam there were the latter ones. Their names were Eliphelet, Jeuel, and Shemaiah, and with them 60 men;
speaker: Narrator

text: from the descendants of Bigvai, Uthai, and Zaccur, and with them 70 men.
speaker: Narrator

text: I had them assemble at the canal that flows toward Ahava, and we camped there for three days. I observed that the people and the priests were present, but I found no Levites there.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I sent for Eliezer, Ariel, Shemaiah, Elnathan, Jarib, Elnathan, Nathan, Zechariah, and Meshullam, who were leaders, and Joiarib and Elnathan, who were teachers.
speaker: Narrator

text: I sent them to Iddo, who was the leader in the place called Casiphia. I told them what to say to Iddo and his relatives, who were the temple servants in Casiphia, so they would bring us attendants for the temple of our God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Due to the fact that the good hand of our God was on us, they brought us a skilled man, from the descendants of Mahli the son of Levi son of Israel. This man was Sherebiah, who was accompanied by his sons and brothers, 18 men;
speaker: Narrator

text: and Hashabiah, along with Jeshaiah from the descendants of Merari, with his brothers and their sons, 20 men;
speaker: Narrator

text: and some of the temple servants that David and his officials had established for the work of the Levites—220 of them. They were all designated by name.
speaker: Narrator

text: I called for a fast there by the Ahava Canal, so that we might humble ourselves before our God and seek from him a safe journey for us, our children, and all our property.
speaker: Narrator

text: I was embarrassed to request soldiers and horsemen from the king to protect us from the enemy along the way, because we had said to the king, “The good hand of our God is on everyone who is seeking him, but his great anger is against everyone who forsakes him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So we fasted and prayed to our God about this, and he answered us.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I set apart twelve of the leading priests, together with Sherebiah, Hashabiah, and ten of their brothers,
speaker: Narrator

text: and I weighed out to them the silver, the gold, and the vessels intended for the temple of our God—items that the king, his advisers, his officials, and all Israel who were present had contributed.
speaker: Narrator

text: I weighed out to them: 650 talents of silver, silver vessels worth 100 talents, 100 talents of gold,
speaker: Narrator

text: 20 gold bowls worth 1,000 darics, and 2 exquisite vessels of gleaming bronze, as valuable as gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I said to them, “You are holy to the Lord, just as these vessels are holy. The silver and the gold are a voluntary offering to the Lord, the God of your fathers.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be careful with them and protect them, until you weigh them out before the leading priests and the Levites and the family leaders of Israel in Jerusalem, in the storerooms of the temple of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the priests and the Levites took charge of the silver, the gold, and the vessels that had been weighed out, to transport them to Jerusalem to the temple of our God.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the twelfth day of the first month we began traveling from the Ahava Canal to go to Jerusalem. The hand of our God was on us, and he delivered us from our enemies and from bandits along the way.
speaker: Narrator

text: So we came to Jerusalem, and we stayed there for three days.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the fourth day we weighed out the silver, the gold, and the vessels in the house of our God into the care of Meremoth son of Uriah, the priest, and Eleazar son of Phinehas, who were accompanied by Jozabad son of Jeshua and Noadiah son of Binnui, who were Levites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Everything was verified by number and by weight, and the total weight was written down at that time.
speaker: Narrator

text: The exiles who were returning from the captivity offered burnt offerings to the God of Israel—twelve bulls for all Israel, ninety-six rams, seventy-seven male lambs, along with twelve male goats as a sin offering. All this was a burnt offering to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they presented the decrees of the king to the king’s satraps and to the governors of Trans-Euphrates, who assisted the people and the temple of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now when these things had been completed, the leaders approached me and said, “The people of Israel, the priests, and the Levites have not separated themselves from the local residents who practice detestable things similar to those of the Canaanites, the Hittites, the Perizzites, the Jebusites, the Ammonites, the Moabites, the Egyptians, and the Amorites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Indeed, they have taken some of their daughters as wives for themselves and for their sons, so that the holy race has become intermingled with the local residents. Worse still, the leaders and the officials have been at the forefront of all this unfaithfulness!”
speaker: Narrator

text: When I heard this report, I tore my tunic and my robe and ripped out some of the hair from my head and beard. Then I sat down, quite devastated.
speaker: Narrator

text: Everyone who held the words of the God of Israel in awe gathered around me because of the unfaithful acts of the people of the exile. Devastated, I continued to sit there until the evening offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the time of the evening offering I got up from my self-abasement, with my tunic and robe torn, and then dropped to my knees and spread my hands to the Lord my God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I prayed:
“O my God, I am ashamed and embarrassed to lift my face to you, my God! For our iniquities have climbed higher than our heads, and our guilt extends to the heavens.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the days of our fathers until this very day our guilt has been great. Because of our iniquities we, along with our kings and priests, have been delivered over by the local kings to sword, captivity, plunder, and embarrassment—right up to the present time.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But now briefly we have received mercy from the Lord our God, in that he has left us a remnant and has given us a secure position in his holy place. Thus our God has enlightened our eyes and has given us a little relief in our time of servitude.
speaker: Narrator

text: Although we are slaves, our God has not abandoned us in our servitude. He has extended kindness to us in the sight of the kings of Persia, in that he has revived us to restore the temple of our God and to raise up its ruins and to give us a protective wall in Judah and Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: “And now what are we able to say after this, our God? For we have forsaken your commandments
speaker: Narrator

text: which you commanded us through your servants the prophets with these words: ‘The land that you are entering to possess is a land defiled by the impurities of the local residents! With their abominations they have filled it from one end to the other with their filthiness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore do not give your daughters in marriage to their sons, and do not take their daughters in marriage for your sons. Do not ever seek their peace or welfare, so that you may be strong and may eat the good of the land and may leave it as an inheritance for your children forever.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Everything that has happened to us has come about because of our wicked actions and our great guilt. Even so, our God, you have exercised restraint toward our iniquities and have given us a remnant such as this.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shall we once again break your commandments and intermarry with these abominable peoples? Would you not be so angered by us that you would wipe us out, with no survivor or remnant?
speaker: Narrator

text: O Lord God of Israel, you are righteous, for we are left as a remnant this day. Indeed, we stand before you in our guilt. However, because of this guilt no one can really stand before you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: While Ezra was praying and confessing, weeping and throwing himself to the ground before the temple of God, a very large crowd of Israelites—men, women, and children alike—gathered around him. The people wept loudly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Shecaniah son of Jehiel, from the descendants of Elam, addressed Ezra:
“We have been unfaithful to our God by marrying foreign women from the local peoples. Nonetheless, there is still hope for Israel in this regard.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore let us enact a covenant with our God to send away all these women and their offspring, in keeping with your counsel, my lord, and that of those who respect the commandments of our God. And let it be done according to the law.
speaker: Narrator

text: Get up, for this matter concerns you. We are with you, so be strong and act decisively!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Ezra got up and made the leading priests and Levites and all Israel take an oath to carry out this plan. And they all took a solemn oath.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Ezra got up from in front of the temple of God and went to the room of Jehohanan son of Eliashib. While he stayed there, he did not eat food or drink water, for he was in mourning over the infidelity of the exiles.
speaker: Narrator

text: A proclamation was circulated throughout Judah and Jerusalem that all the exiles were to be assembled in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Everyone who did not come within three days would thereby forfeit all his property, in keeping with the counsel of the officials and the elders. Furthermore, he himself would be excluded from the assembly of the exiles.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the men of Judah and Benjamin were gathered in Jerusalem within the three days. (It was in the ninth month, on the twentieth day of that month.) All the people sat in the square at the temple of God, trembling because of this matter and because of the rains.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Ezra the priest stood up and said to them, “You have behaved in an unfaithful manner by taking foreign wives! This has contributed to the guilt of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now give praise to the Lord God of your fathers, and do his will. Separate yourselves from the local residents and from these foreign wives.”
speaker: Narrator

text: All the assembly replied in a loud voice: “We will do just as you have said!
speaker: Narrator

text: However, the people are numerous and it is the rainy season. We are unable to stand here outside. Furthermore, this business cannot be resolved in a day or two, for we have sinned greatly in this matter.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let our leaders take steps on behalf of all the assembly. Let all those in our towns who have married foreign women come at an appointed time, and with them the elders of each town and its judges, until the hot anger of our God is turned away from us in this matter.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Only Jonathan son of Asahel and Jahzeiah son of Tikvah were against this, assisted by Meshullam and Shabbethai the Levite.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the exiles proceeded accordingly. Ezra the priest separated out by name men who were leaders in their family groups. They sat down to consider this matter on the first day of the tenth month,
speaker: Narrator

text: and on the first day of the first month they finished considering all the men who had married foreign wives.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was determined that from the descendants of the priests, the following had taken foreign wives: from the descendants of Jeshua son of Jozadak, and his brothers: Maaseiah, Eliezer, Jarib, and Gedaliah.
speaker: Narrator

text: (They gave their word to send away their wives; their guilt offering was a ram from the flock for their guilt.)
speaker: Narrator

text: From the descendants of Immer: Hanani and Zebadiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the descendants of Harim: Maaseiah, Elijah, Shemaiah, Jehiel, and Uzziah.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the descendants of Pashhur: Elioenai, Maaseiah, Ishmael, Nethanel, Jozabad, and Elasah.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the Levites: Jozabad, Shimei, Kelaiah (also known as Kelita), Pethahiah, Judah, and Eliezer.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the singers: Eliashib. From the gatekeepers: Shallum, Telem, and Uri.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the Israelites: from the descendants of Parosh: Ramiah, Izziah, Malkijah, Mijamin, Eleazar, Malkijah, and Benaiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the descendants of Elam: Mattaniah, Zechariah, Jehiel, Abdi, Jeremoth, and Elijah.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the descendants of Zattu: Elioenai, Eliashib, Mattaniah, Jeremoth, Zabad, and Aziza.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the descendants of Bebai: Jehohanan, Hananiah, Zabbai, and Athlai.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the descendants of Bani: Meshullam, Malluch, Adaiah, Jashub, Sheal, and Jeremoth.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the descendants of Pahath Moab: Adna, Kelal, Benaiah, Maaseiah, Mattaniah, Bezalel, Binnui, and Manasseh.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the descendants of Harim: Eliezer, Ishijah, Malkijah, Shemaiah, Shimeon,
speaker: Narrator

text: Benjamin, Malluch, and Shemariah.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the descendants of Hashum: Mattenai, Mattattah, Zabad, Eliphelet, Jeremai, Manasseh, and Shimei.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the descendants of Bani: Maadai, Amram, Uel,
speaker: Narrator

text: Benaiah, Bedeiah, Keluhi,
speaker: Narrator

text: Vaniah, Meremoth, Eliashib,
speaker: Narrator

text: Mattaniah, Mattenai, and Jaasu.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the descendants of Binnui: Shimei,
speaker: Narrator

text: Shelemiah, Nathan, Adaiah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Machnadebai, Shashai, Sharai,
speaker: Narrator

text: Azarel, Shelemiah, Shemariah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Shallum, Amariah, and Joseph.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the descendants of Nebo: Jeiel, Mattithiah, Zabad, Zebina, Jaddai, Joel, and Benaiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: All these had taken foreign wives, and some of them also had children by these women.
speaker: Narrator
